articles.headline: Prince Harry and Meghan to ‘Step Back’ From Royal Duties in Extraordinary Retreat
articles.snippet: The couple said they plan to split time between Britain and North America, with Canada seen as a likely landing spot.
articles.abstract: The couple said they plan to split time between Britain and North America, with Canada seen as a likely landing spot.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a year of gut punches to Britain’s royal family, Prince Harry and his wife, Meghan, delivered a jarring blow of their own on Wednesday, announcing that they would “step back” from their official duties.

articles.headline: The Economy Is Expanding. Why Are Economists So Glum?
articles.snippet: At an annual gathering of the profession, researchers presented evidence and talks that amounted to warnings on the state of the record-long expansion.
articles.abstract: At an annual gathering of the profession, researchers presented evidence and talks that amounted to warnings on the state of the record-long expansion.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — The mood among economic forecasters gathered for their annual meeting last weekend was dark. They warned one another about President Trump’s trade war, about government budget deficits and, repeatedly, about the inability of central banks to fully combat another recession should one sweep the globe anytime soon.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Its Missiles Did Little Damage, but Iran Has More Potent Weapons
articles.snippet: Drones, militants and hackers: Iran has an array of stealthier and more effective options if hostilities escalate.
articles.abstract: Drones, militants and hackers: Iran has an array of stealthier and more effective options if hostilities escalate.
articles.lead_paragraph: American military and intelligence officials were stunned at the precision, scale and sheer boldness of what they later concluded was an Iranian attack.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Ronen Bergman

articles.headline: Carlos Ghosn Defends His Legacy
articles.snippet: “Nobody’s going to take it from me,” said the fugitive former auto mogul, a symbol of globalism under pressure.
articles.abstract: “Nobody’s going to take it from me,” said the fugitive former auto mogul, a symbol of globalism under pressure.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Most global fugitives tend to lie low. They do not beckon reporters to televised news conferences or allow themselves to be photographed drinking wine by candlelight days after being smuggled in a box aboard a chartered jet to freedom.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Michael Corkery

articles.headline: Trump’s Iran Strategy: A Cease-Fire Wrapped in a Strategic Muddle
articles.snippet: Mr. Trump has yet to resolve the two conflicting instincts on national security that emerge from his speeches and his Twitter feed: bellicosity and disengagement.
articles.abstract: Mr. Trump has yet to resolve the two conflicting instincts on national security that emerge from his speeches and his Twitter feed: bellicosity and disengagement.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump opened a small window for diplomacy with Iran on Wednesday, but combined his words with bald threats that made it hard to see how the two countries could break out of their cycle of confrontation and revenge.

articles.headline: 3 Hours From Alert to Attacks: Inside the Race to Protect U.S. Forces From Iran Strikes
articles.snippet: Intelligence that foreshadowed the Iranian attack set off a tense, often confusing afternoon in the White House Situation Room.
articles.abstract: Intelligence that foreshadowed the Iranian attack set off a tense, often confusing afternoon in the White House Situation Room.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The alert came to the White House shortly after 2 p.m. on Tuesday, a flash message from American spy agencies that officials sometimes call a “squawk.” In the coming hours, it warned, an Iranian attack on American troops was almost certain.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Eric Schmitt, Lara Jakes and Thomas Gibbons-Neff

articles.headline: Around the Country in 17 Hours With Michael Bloomberg
articles.snippet: There is a way that people generally run for president. And there is whatever Mr. Bloomberg is doing.
articles.abstract: There is a way that people generally run for president. And there is whatever Mr. Bloomberg is doing.
articles.lead_paragraph: WELLS, Minn. — Michael R. Bloomberg walked among the silos, bundled and reddening in the nine-degree air, negotiating the icy path that delivers a billionaire presidential candidate past the grain bins and the cameras and the tractor — straight into the middle of somewhere his advisers decided he should be.

articles.headline: What the Rebirth of This Old Steel Center Means for Trump
articles.snippet: The Lehigh Valley rebuilt its economy after foreign competition wiped out its mills. Now good times and bad memories may both help the president.
articles.abstract: The Lehigh Valley rebuilt its economy after foreign competition wiped out its mills. Now good times and bad memories may both help the president.
articles.lead_paragraph: BETHLEHEM, Pa. — Just a few blocks from the rusted 16-story blast furnaces that once fired hulking steel beams for the Hoover Dam and the Golden Gate Bridge, OraSure Technologies each day produces thousands of thumbnail-size pads made to spit on.

articles.headline: Facebook Says It Won’t Back Down From Allowing Lies in Political Ads
articles.snippet: The company was under intense pressure to adjust its policies. But in this presidential election year, no big changes are planned.
articles.abstract: The company was under intense pressure to adjust its policies. But in this presidential election year, no big changes are planned.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Defying pressure from Congress, Facebook said on Thursday that it would continue to allow political campaigns to use the site to target advertisements to particular slices of the electorate and that it would not police the truthfulness of the messages sent out.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Cecilia Kang

articles.headline: Iranian Missile Accidentally Brought Down Ukrainian Jet, Officials Say, Citing Early Evidence
articles.snippet: Western intelligence showed that Iran was responsible for the plane crash, suggesting that the deaths of those aboard were a consequence of the heightened tensions between Washington and Iran.
articles.abstract: Western intelligence showed that Iran was responsible for the plane crash, suggesting that the deaths of those aboard were a consequence of the heightened tensions between Washington and Iran.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American and allied officials said on Thursday that they had intelligence that missiles fired by Iranian military forces were responsible for the downing of a Ukrainian jetliner and the deaths of all aboard this week in Iran, most likely by accident.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Eric Schmitt, Anton Troianovski and Natalie Kitroeff
